Question 1.Question: Which subject is this given to you?
Question 1.Explanation: This subject is Government.

Question 2.Question: Power that is delegated is exercised
Question 2.Explanation: A delegated power is exercised indirectly. When power is delegated from one body to another, such body whom the powers is delegated to exercises such power on behalf of the delegating authority. Though the body that makes a delegated legislation was not the original holder of such power, it can exercise it “indirectly” because of the delegation.

Options.Value: Grant
Treaty
Force
Law

Question 3.Question: De jure sovereignty is acquired through
Question 3.Explanation: De jure sovereignty is a sovereignty acquired through the law. It involves expressed institutionally recognized right to exercise control over a territory. De facto or actual sovereignty is concerned with whether control in fact exists. Mostsovereignstates are statesde jureandde facto i.e., they exist both in law and in reality.

Options.Value: Nation-state
Nation
State
Community

Question 4.Question: A group of people who live together under a common law within a definite territory is a
Question 4.Explanation: This group has a clearly defined territory which her citizens and other people reside. They are usually bound by common laws. Nigeria for example is a state.

Options.Value: The transmission of political values
Political transition
Free choice of party programmes
Military takeover of civilian government

Question 5.Question: Political socialization is associated with
Question 5.Explanation: Political socialization is the process by which individuals learn and frequently internalize a political lens, framing their perceptions of how power is arranged and how the world around them is organized.

Options.Value: Aristocracy
Autocracy
Polyarchy
Diarchy

Question 6.Question: According to Aristotle, a form of government in which the few for the benefit of all is
Question 6.Explanation: Aristocracy is a form of government that places strength in the hands of a small, privileged ruling class. The term derives from the Greek “aristokratia”meaning‘rule of the best’.

Options.Value: Gerontocracy
Feudalism
Theocracy
Monarchy

Question 7.Question: Rule by the old people is known as
Question 7.Explanation: In a simplified definition, gerontocracyis a society where leadership is reserved for elders. The best example of this can be seen in the ancient Greek city state of Sparta, which was ruled by the Gerousia. The Gerousia was a council made up of members who were at least 60 years old and served for life.

Options.Value: Writing laws
Giving loans
Making laws
Implementing laws

Question 8.Question: As an executive, the commissioner is charged with the responsibility of
Question 8.Explanation: The executive is the arm of government charged with the implementation of laws made by the legislature. A commissioner or minister is part of an executive team headed by a president.

Options.Value: Executive
Government
Legislature
Judiciary

Question 9.Question: Rule adjudication is a primary function of the
Question 9.Explanation: Rule Adjudication is the legal process by which an arbiter or judge reviews evidence and argumentation, including legal reasoning set forth by opposing parties or litigants to come to a decision which determines rights and obligations between the parties involved. It is the duty of the judiciary.

Options.Value: Judiciary overview
Judicial review
Motions
Delegated legislation

Question 10.Question: The judiciary controls the executive in federal states through
Question 10.Explanation: Through judicial review in the courts, the judiciary curbs and checks the excesses of the executive and legislature. This is one of the fundamentals of the rule of checks and balances.

Options.Value: Distant from the people
Popular among the masses
Strong stable
Free of controversy

Question 11.Question: One major advantage of the unitary system is that it tends to make government
Question 11.Explanation: In a unitary system of government, power is highly concentrated at the center therefore making the government strong, stable and fortified. Ghana has a unitary system of government.

Options.Value: Executive and legislative power are fused
Power of the three arms of government are merged
The tenure of office of the president is limited
The principle of collective responsibility applies

Question 12.Question: The presidential system differs from the parliamentary system of government in that
Question 12.Explanation: The tenure of the president is fixed unlike the parliamentary system where the prime minister remains in office as long as the parliament does not pass a vote of no confidence on him.

Options.Value: Aristocracy
Socialism
Plutocracy
Capitalism

Question 13.Question: Which of the following advocate equitable distribution of wealth?
Question 13.Explanation: Socialist advocates for government ownership of all means of production so as to ensure equitable distribution of wealth while capitalism advocates for private ownership of all means of production.

Options.Value: Written
Unwritten
Flexible
Rigid

Question 14.Question: A constitution that is difficult to amend is
Question 14.Explanation: Nigeria operates on a rigid constitution which as opposed to a flexible one is not easily amended. The steps demanded for amendment is most tasking, difficult and requires the vote of majority of the members of the National Assembly.

Options.Value: Rigid constitution
Written constitution
Flexible constitution
Unwritten constitution

Question 16.Explanation: Devolution involves the transfer of power to an autonomic lower level, especially by a central government to a local regional administration.

Question 17.Explanation: As against citizenship by naturalization and registration, citizenship by birth is the strongest and inalienable connection between a citizen and his country.

Options.Value: Nationality suffrage
Electoral suffrage

Question 18.Question: The right of citizens to vote is
Question 18.Explanation: Once a person is of the age stipulated by the law of the land to vote, such person should not be denied the opportunity to do so except for reasonable grounds as stipulated by the law.

Strategy
Source of finance

Question 19.Question: A political party is different from a pressure group in its
Question 19.Explanation: The objective of political parties is to serve as a platform through which borders emerge and rule by winning elections. Pressure groups are not inclined to the aforementioned purpose.

Articulate the opinion of their members

Question 20.Question: One of the functions of pressure groups is to
Question 20.Explanation: A pressure group may be defined as any group of people bound together by some common interest or profession who engage in some activities to influence government policies to their own advantage.

Views of the Chief Justice of a country
Aggregate of attitudes held by members of the national assembly
Aggregate views of groups on particular government activities

Question 21.Question: Public opinion refers to the
Question 21.Explanation: Public opinion is one of the strong arms of control citizens have in a democratic setting. It involves the totality of views held by different factions and groups on specific activities, dealings and actions of government.

Options.Value: Clerical
Technical
Administrative
Executive

Question 22.Question: The class that oversees the implementation of government decisions and policies is the
Question 22.Explanation: The executive class implements the general policies and programme of the government on a daily basis. They supervise and control the activities of their subordinates and help to collect facts that aids in making policy decision.

Ogboni
Oyo mesi
Aare ona kakanfo

Question 23.Question: The performance of ritual rite in the Yoruba empire is the responsibility of the
Question 23.Explanation:
OGBONI

The Ogboni was one of the top most political & religious institutions in the Yoruba empires. The Ogboni represented the popular opinion backed by the authority of religion, and therefore the views of the Oyomesi could be moderated by the Ogboni.They were prominent for the performance of ritual rites.

Question 24.Explanation:

Question 25.Question: The indirect rule system of administration was more successful in Northern Nigeria because
Question 25.Explanation: There was the existence of an organized structure in the area, so the British never saw the need for a total overhaul of the institutions present there. It was well balanced, organized and well suited to the colonial policy and still kept the people amenable to their Islamic sentiments.

Question 26.Question: The earliest nationalist activities in Nigeria were spearheaded by
Question 26.Explanation: The educated elites such as Herbert Macaulay and Nnamdi Azikiwe spearheaded the nationalist activities. The colonial government did not let the educated elites pick up meaningful posts in government, organizations and the civil service but preferred to relate with the traditional rulers. This began the nationalist activities by the educated elites.

Question 27.Explanation: The NCBWA was formed in 1917 and was largely composed of educated elites in West Africa. It was co-founded by Thomas Hutton Mills, J.E. Casely Hayford, Edward Francis and Kobina Sekyi and so on.

Question 28.Explanation: Nigeria operated the parliamentary system in the first republic (1960 – 1963). In this system, the executive and legislative powers were fused in the Prime Minister during that era.

Question 32.Explanation: Code of Conduct Bureau is the pioneer anti-corruption agency set up by the Federal Government of Nigeria. It has the primary responsibility of checking corrupt practices in the Nigerian Public service and has been doing so since 1989.

Question 33.Explanation: Under the third republic, only two political parties were allowed to contest for elections by the military government; National Republic Convention (NRC) and Social Democratic Party (SDP).

Question 34.Explanation: For the fear of dominating the minorities, Nigeria adopted a federal system of government as against the unitary system of government. In this system, government was brought closer to the people through components unit.

Question 35.Explanation: General Yakubu Gowon established the Supreme Military Council and held power until July 1975, when he was overthrown in a bloody coup.
